title: Nymph of the Lo River
text:
The classical narrative poem, Nymph of the Lo River, written by Tsao-chih (192-232) is the subject of this elegantly brushed handscroll. The story recounts an abortive love affair between a poet and a river goddess. The verse, one of the standards of Chinese literature, became a favorite subject of literati artists. Attached to the painted portion of this scroll, dated 1591, is a transcription of the Nymph of the Lo River by the late Ming calligrapher, Ku Meng-yu, dated 1654.

The painting is executed in the "fine line" technique called pai-miao that matured during the Sung-Yuan period (11th-14th century). Although the style demands extraordinary brush control, Wang has creatively alternated areas of dry, textured brushwork with calculated, even, wire-like lineation to add a sense of spontaneity and liveliness to the composition. Only a few paintings by Wang Shang-kung reside in western collections.
description: image of woman rising out of a body of water, wearing a billowing garment and surrounded by waves; 8 men on shore observe woman, with 10 other men further from shore; image followed by panel of text
